content: Interestingly enough, the current suggested solution relies on a combination of bugs of the platform: As it raises an exception after printing the proper answer, it is considered correct in the IDE but not by the automatic solution checking system. It is then a kind of valid solution that theoretically could not have been accepted by the contribution system, but yet has been, probably because of this other bug https://forum.codingame.com/t/contribution-system-small-improvements/162318/9

I've just played this and faced a problem. My code passed all tests, but failed on a validator. The same happened to another player (hiljusti) that was on the same clash. Both of us used the "tr" function (that in my opinion seems to be the best tool for this kind of problem), I used Ruby and he/she used Bash.
I've just checked that the problem is on the last validator, it includes the substring "S-)" on the alphabet making "tr" raise an exception, as it tries to create a range from "S" to ")".
My suggestion is to add a similar substring to the test as well, so people that use the "tr" function will notice this corner case.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice Coc. Simple and with a short statement.
The challenge is OK, but why so many people think that shorter code means more understandable or better code? Have you ever been assigned to maintain a project created by someone with this ideology?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it can be solved with only two lines in Python

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a simple and solvable problem.
I did it in minds of the code golf challenge :) I would obviously never use anything remotely as compact as this for production
Not a bad idea, yet because of what I say in my comment above, it is currently impossible to edit the testcases without also modifying the solution.

I'm pretty sure that the automatic solution checker accepts this as well. I think I should have probably not golfed my solution code, to avoid such issues, but If I encountered this problem in a golfing clash, that's the way that I would solve it with the current state of the platform. Anyways, I've rewritten my solution to be more verbose and avoid such bugs, so that it would still work if these bugs were to be fixed.

> "I'm pretty sure that the automatic solution checker accepts this as well."
It did not, that's how I knew about the bug (the automatic checker probably rejects if the exit code is not 0 while the IDE validation only cares about the std output).
If I remember correctly, you only had to replace the last i() (used for the output) by a print() though.
Yes, that would have been enough to mitigate this issue, but @Velcoro also said that it is probably not a nice Idea to have a golfed solution, so I decided to completely rewrite it into a nicer way.

Well, my belief is, that the solution is (for verifying that the test cases are doable, and) for allowing other contributors to understand the intended task, so that it can be compared to the description. If I created a code golf challenge and showed 40 chars Perl ascii chaos to show how short it can be, it simply doesn't fulfill this role.

Anyway, the challenge is nice, thumbs up!
I've updated the solution now to be more verbose
